sections.markdown:
# Using Dynatrace Workflows and Site Reliability Guardian to analysis performance and automate process
#
## Overview
---
#
Duration: 20 min
#
### Use Case:
#
* Create a SRG with multiple SLOs to evaluate, which you can automate to be evaluated with a workflow.
#
### What you will learn today:
#
Today you are going to learn how to create an SRG, define an SLO and create a workflow to automate processes.
#

### In this lab you're going to do:
#
1. Create a SRG using a template.
2. Validation of the SRG with the defined objectives.
3. Automate the SRG with workflows.

# Create the Site Reliability Guardian

The Site Reliability Guardian (SRG), allow us to evaluate objectives previosuly created (SLOs), define new objectives using DQL that can be based on performance or security metric.

## Step 1: Create a SRG usign a template.
On the Site Reliability Guardian app, we are going to click on the "+ Guardian" button, this going to start the process to create a new guardian, it's goign to show a page with multiple template to choose and not start from scratch.
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
#
For this case, we are going to use the "Four goldens signals", to select it we are going to click on the "Use template" button, once you selected it, a section with a predefined DQL, you have to execute it and after that you have to select the service "easyTradeLoginService" which we will select for this exercise.
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
#
After you select the service, now you are going to see the 4 golden signals applied to the service you select before, on the right side you have to change the new of the Guardian adding at the end your name, you can modify the descriptrion or add tags.
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
#
If we select one of the defined objectives, you can see the DQL used for that golden signal and the section where you can define the threshold that you want or leave with the auto-adatative threshold.
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
#
After you finalize the objectives definition and thresholds, you can save the SRG.

## Step 2: Validation of the SRG and the objectives defined.
#
Now that you have created the SRG, you can evaluate it using a timeframe of 2 hours, you can evaluate it on the upper-right corner on the "validate" button, after you execute it, below you are going to see the historial of the previous executions, if you select one, you are going to see at the end the results from that execution. 
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)

## Step 3: Automate the SRG with workflows.
#
We are going to do the automation of the SRG using a workflow, on the upper-right corner you are going the click on then"Automate" button, after that it's going to create a workflow with a predefined trigger to receive a release event with these values `service == "carts" AND stage == "production"`, please make you sure you have it defined and it's configured with the  `events` type. 
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
#
The second step is to confirm is selected the SRG you created before and select the timeframe to be 2 hours.
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)

For the third step, we have to add the "Email for workflows", you are going to fill the "To" field with your email, in the Subject field copy the following string `Release validation for {{ result("run_validation")["guardian_name"] }}`, finally in the "Message" field copy the following message: 
```Results from the last evaluation:

Failed objectives: {{ result("run_validation")["validation_summary"]["fail"] }}
Info objectives: {{ result("run_validation")["validation_summary"]["info"] }}
Pass objectives: {{ result("run_validation")["validation_summary"]["pass"] }}
Error objectives: {{ result("run_validation")["validation_summary"]["error"] }}
Warning objectives: {{ result("run_validation")["validation_summary"]["warning"] }}

Here the details for each objective:

The objective {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].0. name }} with status {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].0.status }}, get the following values  {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].0.value }}s with objective as {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].0.target }}s
The objective {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].1. name }} with status {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].1.status }}, get the following values {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].1.value }} errors
The objective {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].2. name }} with status {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].2.status }}, get the following values {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].2.value }} average of requests
The objective {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].3. name }} with status {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].3.status }}, get the following values {{ result("run_validation")["validation_details"].3.value }} use of memory 
```
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)
# 
After that, in the section of  "Conditions" you have the option "Run this task if" select for the "run validation" to be "success".
#
Now we can execute the workflow, after the validation it's goign to send the results via email.
#
Finally, you have to make public the workflow, to be visible for everyone.
#
![](data:image/webp;base64,)

## Wrap Up
___
#
### Lab recap
#
Today with the help of the Dynatrace platform you see how to create a Site Reliability Guardian, make the evaluation of the objectives and automate the test using the workflows.
#
What you learned today:
#
1. Create a SRG using a template.
2. Validate the SRG and the defined objectives.
3. Automate the SRG with workflows.
#
